title: Will casualties from the Turkey-PKK conflict exceed 125 in any month from August through November 2017, according to the International Crisis Group?

The historical base rate of casualties was near 50%.  However, the trend over the last 6 months was well below 125 casualties, and a number of Muslim holidays are scheduled in the upcoming months. I'm waiting for the site to update before any further adjustment, but if one considers the period from December 2016 only, the probability will be in single figures.

According to the Crisis Group, over three-thousand people have died since the end of the ceasefire between Turkey and the PKK in 2015.  The monthly graph provided on the Crisis Group's site shows a trend of increasing violence since May.  With the decline of ISIS and an upcoming Kurdish referendum on independence, the potential for violence between Turkey and the PKK has heightened.  Although the political climate is ripe for violence between the two groups, the threshold of 125 casualties has been unmet since October of last year.  Putting aside all numerical data, I believe the Kurdish referendum in September will trigger violence between the two groups which will lead to over 125 casualties in a single month up to and including November.

Casualties, definitionally and methodologically include both deaths and casualties.  ICG restricts the domain of actors to those killed and confirmed fatalities.  It excludes cases from its count that are unconfirmed.  This further restricts the domain of the two actors in conflict interactions: the Turkish state, its officers, police and other officials along with PKK insurgents and its proxies.  Turkey views the PKK as a terror group, while the PKK is engaged in a political and military struggle for independence.  Since the cessation of a relatively short period of conflict and an unsuccessful coup against the state, the two sets of actors have intensified their asymmetric non-zero-sum game of terror and counterterror.  Given this dynamic we should expect the counts to move above the threshold, however, restrictions on the range for counts in 4 groups will be reduced.  Depending on the military tactics employed by the PKK, and the constrained definitions in counting methods, this should reduce the total number of casualties counted by ICG.   Additional data sources would indicate support for crossing the threshold but the constraint explanation reasonably accounts for variances in actual versus the constrained casualties counted.

Well since the breakdown of the ceasefire, casualties have exceeded 125 for 11 months and been under for 14 months. As well, casualties have been declining this year. That said, there are a lot of factors that could lead to an increase in violence, such as more aggressive moves by the Turkish army, extra arms flowing from the US to Kurds in Syria, and the possibility of another attack in an urban area (there hasn't been one since last year).
